newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: British lawyer rips into Singapore prime minister.
newsitem.headline: British lawyer rips into Singapore prime minister.

text.p: A top British lawyer accused Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Tuesday of paying lip-service to full democratic principles and using the courts to oust an opposition politician from parliament.

"This litigation is designed to bankrupt this man to keep him out of Parliament," George Carman told the High Court as he cross examined Goh in a series of defamation cases against Workers' Party (WP) leader Joshua Jeyaretnam.

"One way of making a member of parliament bankrupt...is to use the heavy artillery of multiple actions to obtain massive damages," he said. "Is that part of your strategy?" he asked Goh. The Prime Minister denied any such intent.

"You and your 10 political colleagues saw this as a method of causing financial oppression on this 71-year-old man because you wanted him out of parliament and thought the court would provide a convenient method," said Carman.
"No. Mr Jeyaretnam is not a threat to the PAP," responded Goh in reference to his ruling People's Action Party (PAP), which has run Singapore since it became self-governing in 1959.
In an intense barrage of questions, Carman suggested Goh was paying "lip-service to having the full rights of a democracy".
Goh, his predecessor, Lee Kuan Yew, and nine other PAP leaders accuse Jeyaretnam of defaming them at a last rally before January 2 elections in which the PAP won 81 of 83 seats.
Jeyaretnam told the rally a fellow WP candidate had filed police reports against the PAP leaders accusing them of lying.
"Mr Tang Liang Hong has just placed before me two reports he has made to police against, you know, Mr Goh Chok Tong and his people," Jeyaretnam told the rally.

Carman said that was "part and parcel of the cut and thrust of politics" which caused no damage to Goh's reputation. Goh's counsel, Tom Shields, another top London libel lawyer, said it amounted to an endorsement of Tang's widely publicised charges.
"It is as if Tang had prepared a Molotov cocktail and gave it to Mr Jeyaretnam and at that precise moment hurled it," Goh said.

The trial is being monitored by human rights groups like the Geneva-based International Commission of Jurists and Amnesty International, which says it is concerned at reports Singapore has used defamation suits to limit free speech.
The PAP leadership denies using the courts to silence the opposition. It is a question, Goh has said, of challenging allegations that would undermine his ability to govern.
The case against Jeyaretnam is the second this year against a WP member. The first also stemmed from the election campaign in which the PAP turned all its weapons on Tang.
They accused Tang of being "an anti-Christian, Chinese chauvinist" who endangered racial harmony in predominantly ethnic Chinese Singapore, which has substantial minorities of Malays and Indians.
Goh and his colleagues sued Tang over a variety of comments, including the lying charge. Tang fled Singapore saying his life had been threatened and did not return to defend himself.
The cases were awarded to the PAP leaders. They won a record S$8.08 million (US$5.65 million) in damages and then sued Jeyaretnam, accusing him of endorsing Tang's charge of lying.
Carman said Jeyaretnam had not endorsed Tang's statements and he questioned why the PAP had sued his client.
Was it because Jeyaretnam, a lawyer, had acted for Tang? Was it in any way connected to this? Carman asked.
"If you are suggesting that we took action because he appeared for Mr Tang, that is completely wrong," Goh said.
But Carman said Goh had filed an affadavit arguing Jeyaretnam's alleged defamation was motivated by malice because "of his conduct when he acted as counsel for Mr Tang".

"I really have to say you have not been truthful with the courtroom in the last five minutes," Carman told Goh, who denied the charge but conceded there was "a connection" between the suits and Jeyaretnam's defence of Tang.
